posts.title_en: You‚Äôve Found Your Archetype. Now What?
posts.content_en:
Learning isn‚Äôt the same as understanding. And understanding isn‚Äôt the same as taking action.

üìå Already know your archetype?
Great. You‚Äôve taken one of the most important steps ‚Äî meeting your true self.
Not the social mask.
Not the version others projected onto you.
But the part that has always been there.

It might be the Wolf. The Wanderer. The Magician. The Cat. The Trickster. The Hero. Or maybe even the Rat.
Whoever you saw ‚Äî the body doesn‚Äôt lie.
When you feel a reaction ‚Äî goosebumps, tightness in your chest, a sense of awe ‚Äî that‚Äôs the sign. That‚Äôs it.
But‚Ä¶ what comes next?

‚ùó Just knowing doesn‚Äôt change anything
The world is full of people who know things.
Some know their shadow. Some ‚Äî their astrological chart. Others ‚Äî their Myers-Briggs type.
So what?
No knowledge will change your life unless you do something with it.
It‚Äôs like finding a flashlight ‚Äî and never turning it on.
You can carry it in your pocket for years. And still stumble through the dark your whole life.

üß≠ An archetype is not a label. It‚Äôs a direction.
An archetype isn‚Äôt a sign that says ‚Äúthis is who I am.‚Äù
It‚Äôs a compass.
It doesn‚Äôt give answers ‚Äî it asks questions.
It opens doors.
But stepping through those doors ‚Äî that‚Äôs your part.

üõ†Ô∏è What‚Äôs on this website?
We‚Äôve created guides for each archetype. Not just ‚Äúdescriptions‚Äù, but:

  • what‚Äôs strong in you ‚Äî and how to activate it;
  • what traps might appear along the path;
  • how not to get stuck in theory;
  • which specific actions will energize you;
  • how your path sounds.

These guides help you move from knowledge to practice.

üóùÔ∏è Who is this for?
For those ready to go further.
Not just ‚Äúreading something interesting.‚Äù
But trying. Feeling. Doing.
That‚Äôs why the guides are in a private Telegram channel ‚Äî not to limit, but to focus.
It‚Äôs for those who are ready.

üî• If you‚Äôre still asking ‚Äúwhat next?‚Äù
Take action. A small one ‚Äî but your own.
Read the guide. Write down one question from it.
Try one recommendation. Not all of them ‚Äî just one.
That‚Äôs enough to start the movement.

Because otherwise, the archetype will remain just a word.
And your essence ‚Äî will never awaken.

posts.title_en: Archetypes in Everyday Life: Closer Than You Think
posts.content_en:
ü§î Think archetypes are just for armchair psychologists, fantasy characters, or spiritual gurus?
Nope.
Archetypes are everyday life in its purest form.
It‚Äôs you when you make a decision. When you crack a joke. When you lose it. When you support someone. When you run away.
An archetype isn‚Äôt something you have to ‚Äúbelieve in.‚Äù
It works whether you know about it or not.

üßç‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Morning: who gets you out of bed?

  • If you jump up thinking ‚Äúthe world awaits ‚Äî and I‚Äôve got a shovel‚Äù ‚Äî that‚Äôs the Hero.
  • If your first thought is ‚Äúwhat fresh nonsense is this life again?‚Äù ‚Äî the Trickster is smiling.
  • If you slowly open one eye and whisper ‚Äújust give me silence and coffee‚Äù ‚Äî welcome, the Cat is waking up.

‚òï In conversations:

  • You listen, care, give advice ‚Äî that‚Äôs the Caregiver.
  • You cut through fluff and get to the point ‚Äî the Sage.
  • You joke, poke, provoke ‚Äî gently but sharply ‚Äî Trickster‚Äôs in the game.
  • You get irritated by others‚Äô helplessness and want to solve everything yourself ‚Äî that‚Äôs an exhausted Hero.

üß± At work or at home:

  • If you‚Äôre being used again and silently endure ‚Äî the Caregiver in shadow.
  • If you want to burn it all down and escape to the mountains ‚Äî the Rebel is chain-smoking in the corner.
  • If you‚Äôve made your coffee, put on headphones and vanished ‚Äî the Wanderer in office attire.
  • If you're watching another video about the meaning of life and opening your third eye ‚Äî the Magician draws near.

üí¨ In dialogue:

  • ‚ÄúI know what‚Äôs best.‚Äù ‚Äî that‚Äôs the Sage getting a bit too comfy.
  • ‚ÄúI told you so, but you‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî the Caregiver‚Äôs Shadow + a dash of Rat.
  • ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs imagine we‚Äôre dancing on the rooftop of the world?‚Äù ‚Äî pure Lover.
  • ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt touch me, I just want to exist.‚Äù ‚Äî always, the Cat.

üìå And now, the main point:
These aren‚Äôt ‚Äúroles‚Äù or ‚Äútraits‚Äù. These are archetypes.
And they‚Äôre not fixed.
You can be a Hero in the morning, a Sage in conversation, a Trickster in the comments, and a Cat with a cup of tea in the evening.
That‚Äôs normal.

üéØ Why does it matter?
Because the moment you realize who‚Äôs acting in you ‚Äî the autopilot disappears.
You‚Äôre no longer ‚Äújust snapped.‚Äù
You see: ‚ÄúThe Rebel‚Äôs driving me right now. Why? What hit him?‚Äù
And in that moment ‚Äî freedom.
Because once you see it, you can choose.

üõ† How to start?

  • Observe. No judgment. Just note it: ‚ÄúWhoa, that was definitely the Magician.‚Äù
  • Read the guide. We‚Äôve got one for each archetype ‚Äî not for decoration, but for action.
  • Allow yourself to be many things. A person isn‚Äôt one archetype. You‚Äôve got a whole pack inside.
  • Don‚Äôt try to be ‚Äòperfect‚Äô. Even the Trickster slips in a puddle sometimes ‚Äî and laughs at it.

üí¨ The Bottom Line
An archetype isn‚Äôt something ‚Äúgrand and lofty.‚Äù
It‚Äôs something ordinary ‚Äî but invisible.
It shapes your yes and no, your choices, your reactions, your actions.
And only you can become aware of it ‚Äî and start working with it.
Because the real path isn‚Äôt about ‚Äúbecoming someone.‚Äù
It‚Äôs about remembering who you already are.

posts.title_en: "To look at yourself" ‚Äî why is it fear for some and a revelation for others?
posts.content_en:
It might seem that seeing your true self is something simple.

What‚Äôs the big deal? Look in the mirror, see who you are ‚Äî and done.

But no, my friend. For many, it‚Äôs scarier than death.

Because what exactly will you see?

Not a pretty mask.
Not ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a father, a worker, a citizen‚Äù.
But that inner one ‚Äî forgotten, neglected, real.
And it‚Äôs not always bright in there.

For most ‚Äî it‚Äôs taboo.

They feel:

‚ÄúIf I look inside ‚Äî I‚Äôll see pain, anger, shame, fear. The things I‚Äôve hidden all my life.‚Äù

And they‚Äôre right.

Because you can‚Äôt fool yourself. In there, everything‚Äôs honest.

And that‚Äôs exactly why most ‚Äî those ‚Äúnormal,‚Äù ‚Äúsuccessful,‚Äù ‚Äústable‚Äù ones ‚Äî prefer not to look.

But what happens if you do look?

First ‚Äî a chill.

Then ‚Äî doubt, fear, nausea.

And then ‚Äî freedom.

Because you no longer waste strength maintaining the fake.

And then curiosity appears.

The kind a child has, but deeper:

  • "Who else am I?"
  • "What else is inside me?"
  • "Why am I like this?"
  • "And if I can change ‚Äî who do I want to become?"

And that‚Äôs where the path begins.

Some won‚Äôt walk it. And that‚Äôs okay too.

They‚Äôll live in their masks, in their ‚ÄúI‚Äôm busy with more serious things.‚Äù

But those who‚Äôve taken the first step ‚Äî won‚Äôt go back.

Because the real ‚Äî it‚Äôs more interesting, even when it hurts.

It‚Äôs not for everyone. And thank God.

It‚Äôs not a contest.

It‚Äôs not ‚Äúenlightenment‚Äù or ‚Äútrendy self-growth.‚Äù

It‚Äôs simply a choice: to live with yourself ‚Äî or next to yourself.

If you‚Äôre curious ‚Äî welcome.

If you‚Äôre scared ‚Äî that‚Äôs good too. Fear is a reaction.

But if you feel absolutely nothing ‚Äî then maybe it‚Äôs exactly time to look inside.

‚ÄúI am‚Äù ‚Äî is about this.

About silence, truth, the inner touch of self.

Not fast. Not guaranteed. But ‚Äî real.

About home.

Inside ‚Äî it‚Äôs not always light. But it‚Äôs not empty either.

Imagine an old abandoned house.

Outside ‚Äî peeling walls, cracks, dust, empty windows.

Many are even afraid to enter:

  • ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs dark in there,‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúIt might be dangerous,‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúBetter stay away.‚Äù

But the one who enters ‚Äî carefully, holding a lamp ‚Äî sees:

Yes, there‚Äôs trash, broken furniture, cobwebs.

But also ‚Äî solid walls, a strong foundation, and hidden treasures.

With some patience, some effort ‚Äî the house gets cleaned.

It becomes more than just a shelter.

It becomes a fortress. A place of power.

Cleansing yourself ‚Äî is the same.

You enter this house. Yourself.

At first steps, dust rises in clouds.

Everything seems worse than it looked from outside.

But you‚Äôre no longer afraid ‚Äî

You know: it‚Äôs just dust. Not monsters.

And you start small:

  • Cleaned here,
  • Looked there,
  • Threw something out,
  • Kept something else.

What‚Äôs no longer yours ‚Äî you let go with gratitude.

What‚Äôs truly yours ‚Äî you clean, repair, return to its place.

With each day ‚Äî more light.

The cracks on the walls are no longer shame. They‚Äôre part of the beauty.

This house ‚Äî it‚Äôs not perfect. But it‚Äôs alive.

And most importantly ‚Äî it‚Äôs yours.

You‚Äôre no longer a guest in yourself.

You ‚Äî are the owner.

When you clean the house ‚Äî the inner light appears.

And then ‚Äî light begins to seep through the windows from outside.

You step onto the porch.

Look around.

There are other houses.

Some abandoned too.

Some ‚Äî dark.

And in some ‚Äî lights already flicker.

And then comes the most important realization:

You ‚Äî are not alone.

And you no longer have to save anyone.

You simply are.

Alive.

Real.

Someone who walked through the darkness ‚Äî and remained themselves.

And that ‚Äî is the greatest thing a person can do.

To be a light that forces nothing, but can be seen even in the thickest darkness.

Date: May 19, 2025

This question often comes up right after someone first encounters the idea of archetypes.

  • ‚ÄúSo okay, I‚Äôm a Wolf... or a Caregiver... or a Wanderer. So what?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúIs it like a zodiac sign?‚Äù
    • ‚ÄúIs this just for fun?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúDo I even need this?‚Äù

And the answer is simple: if you don‚Äôt want to ‚Äî you don‚Äôt have to.
But if you want to live more deeply ‚Äî an archetype can be a key.

An archetype isn‚Äôt a clich√©, a box, or a diagnosis.
It‚Äôs more like an inner engine that‚Äôs been running for ages ‚Äî you just didn‚Äôt know what it looked like or what it was pulling.
You feel something constantly at work inside you, pushing you toward certain actions, resonating with certain topics, people, situations.
And when you suddenly see your archetype ‚Äî a lot falls into place.
It‚Äôs like naming your way of life, your inner language.

And then:

  • You understand why you act the way you do.
  • The feeling of ‚Äúsomething‚Äôs wrong with me‚Äù disappears.
  • A sense of respect for yourself appears. Not pride ‚Äî steady dignity.

This isn‚Äôt a wrapper ‚Äî it‚Äôs your core.
You can be a Caregiver ‚Äî and stop being ashamed that caring matters to you.
You can be a Rebel ‚Äî and finally understand why ‚Äúnormal life‚Äù gets under your skin.
You can be a Lover ‚Äî and stop fearing your sensitivity, giving it space instead.
Or maybe you‚Äôre a Wolf ‚Äî and you just need to get out of the cage.
And then you don‚Äôt need to invent ‚Äúmotivation‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs already there.
You simply allow yourself to be yourself.

It‚Äôs not an ‚Äúexcuse‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs awareness.
You don‚Äôt say: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a Warrior, so I‚Äôm harsh.‚Äù
But you might say: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a Warrior. And now I understand how to direct that power ‚Äî not to destroy, but to create.‚Äù

An archetype also explains your conflicts.
Sometimes you argue not because someone‚Äôs bad ‚Äî but because you have different archetypes, different languages, different wounds.
She‚Äôs a Mage, and you‚Äôre a Leader.
You‚Äôre not enemies. You just see the world differently.

And most importantly: an archetype is not a label.
It‚Äôs a compass.
When you‚Äôre lost, when you don‚Äôt know where to go, when you feel out of place or not yourself ‚Äî the archetype can be the point you return home from.
It‚Äôs not about being perfect. It‚Äôs about being honest with yourself.

So, to put it simply:
Why know your archetype?

  • To understand yourself.
  • To stop wasting energy fighting your own nature.
  • To find your path ‚Äî not copy someone else‚Äôs.
  • To respect yourself. And those who are different.
  • To stop hiding. And finally live.

It‚Äôs not mandatory.
But if it resonates ‚Äî maybe it‚Äôs time.

posts.title_en: The Funniest Tragedy of Humanity ‚Äî Memory in the Shadows
posts.content_en:
Date: May 20, 2025

Consciousness ‚Äî like some dude with amnesia living in an archive

Imagine three characters:

  • The Body ‚Äî an old grandpa who remembers everything. And not just remembers, but grumbles:
    ‚ÄúRemember back in ‚Äô97, when you said ‚Äòit‚Äôs fine‚Äô instead of ‚Äòno, that hurts‚Äô? That‚Äôs why it twitches here now.‚Äù
  • The Subconscious ‚Äî the archivist sitting in the dark, smoking in the corner and whispering from time to time:
    ‚ÄúThis one‚Äôs from a past life... no need to thank me.‚Äù
  • And finally, Consciousness ‚Äî basically Vasya with amnesia.
    He‚Äôs running through the warehouse, looking around and yelling:
    ‚ÄúWhy do I feel so awful? What‚Äôs that smell? Why do I want to cry when it rains and smells like apples?!‚Äù

High-grade absurdity

We make decisions every day ‚Äî live, love, work ‚Äî without full access to who we really are.

And the body, like a loyal dog, endures:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, he‚Äôll get there. We‚Äôll wait. Look, he‚Äôs got goosebumps ‚Äî maybe he‚Äôs starting to remember something.‚Äù

And the subconscious sighs:
‚ÄúFine, I‚Äôll toss him another dream. Maybe he‚Äôll catch the hint.‚Äù

The funniest and scariest thing at once

You might not remember why it drives you mad when someone interrupts you.
Might not know why a certain smell makes you want to run.
Might not understand why you feel bad around someone who‚Äôs smiling at you.
But the body knows.

And the subconscious pushes.

And you, poor Vasya-the-Consciousness, stand there in the middle of it all asking:
‚ÄúDid I screw something up again?‚Äù

So how do you live in this madness?

  • Don‚Äôt panic.
    You‚Äôre not tripping ‚Äî you just started listening. And that‚Äôs already 90% of the work.
  • Trust your body.
    If something reacts ‚Äî don‚Äôt ignore it. It‚Äôs not ‚Äúnonsense,‚Äù it‚Äôs mail from the depths.
  • Observe.
    Ask yourself: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs speaking in me right now? Is it really me ‚Äî or the archive?‚Äù
  • Don‚Äôt rush.
    This isn‚Äôt a sprint. This is life. And it‚Äôll throw you more riddles either way.

The conclusion is simple as wire:

Consciousness isn‚Äôt the boss.

It‚Äôs the translator between worlds.

And when you start treating it as a tool, not the center of the universe ‚Äî oh, that‚Äôs when things get interesting.

Because a door opens.

And you‚Äôre no longer just Vasya ‚Äî
you‚Äôre someone who remembers more than yesterday.

posts.title_en: Why Do People Choose Suffering Over Change?
posts.content_en:
Date: May 24, 2025

This isn‚Äôt just psychology.

This is already the philosophy of pain, with a touch of tragedy and a full-blown absurdist theater.

Because, really ‚Äî it seems simple:

  • You're suffering? ‚Äî Change.
  • Life sucks? ‚Äî Take action.
  • Unhappy? ‚Äî Find a way out.

But no.

Many prefer the familiar pain to the unknown ‚Äî even if the unknown might be better.

Why is that?

1. Suffering is familiar. Change is terrifying.

Better the swamp you know than a shore you don‚Äôt.

People live in pain for years, but they‚Äôve learned how to survive there.

Change means responsibility, choice, a new role.

And that‚Äôs terrifying.

2. Suffering becomes an excuse.

‚ÄúI would do something, but, you know‚Ä¶ wrong time, wrong place‚Ä¶‚Äù

When you‚Äôre suffering, it feels like you‚Äôre doing something ‚Äî but really, you're just enduring.

It‚Äôs a kind of inner indulgence:

‚ÄúI‚Äôm suffering ‚Äî so I must be trying.‚Äù

3. Suffering is social currency.

‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs struggling. No big deal. Just hang in there.‚Äù

When you‚Äôre in pain, people pity you. Support you. Leave you alone.

But the moment you start changing ‚Äî

they either don‚Äôt understand, or they get scared, or they dismiss you:

  • ‚ÄúWhat, you think you‚Äôre better now?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúGo get a real job.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt mess with fate.‚Äù

4. Suffering becomes your identity.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the victim. The martyr. The unlucky one.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a role. A persona. A protective mask.

And even if it hurts ‚Äî it‚Äôs familiar.

Without it ‚Äî there‚Äôs emptiness.

5. And the deepest one: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt deserve better.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll fail.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not for people like me.‚Äù
‚ÄúStuff like that doesn‚Äôt happen to someone like me.‚Äù

This is the root.

It‚Äôs not a thought ‚Äî it‚Äôs a belief.

Formed in childhood, shaped by experience, reinforced by others‚Äô words:

  • ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll never amount to anything.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not for you.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúCalm down, dreamer.‚Äù

So the person grows up ‚Äî but the belief stays.

And they won‚Äôt let themselves out of the pit.

Because they believe the pit is where they belong.

So what do you do with all this?

Don‚Äôt fight everything at once.

Don‚Äôt burn your old identity to the ground.

Don‚Äôt scream ‚ÄúI must change EVERYTHING!‚Äù

Start small:

  • Listen to yourself.
    Where does it hurt? Where can‚Äôt you take it anymore? Where are you tired of staying silent?
  • Tell yourself the truth.
    Not the world. Not others. Just yourself.
  • Allow yourself to imagine another version.
    Not perfect ‚Äî just different. A little lighter. A little freer.
  • Make one small move.
    Any move. But in the direction of light, not rot.

And don‚Äôt wait for support.

Support may come later. Or not at all.

And that‚Äôs okay.

Because this is your choice.
Your move.
Your strength.

And most importantly:

You‚Äôre no longer the one who just endures.

You‚Äôre the one who sees, feels, and seeks.

And that already means a lot.

Date: June 5, 2025

How we program ourselves and each other

Imagine you're not talking to a person, but to a computer.
You type in a command ‚Äî and wait for the result.
If the command is written correctly, the program runs.
If it‚Äôs crooked ‚Äî it freezes or crashes.

Same with people.
Except instead of a command line ‚Äî we use words.
They‚Äôre like code.
And how we choose them determines what a person "outputs" in response:
Understanding or hurt, cooperation or resistance.

üü¶ 1. A word as a command

You say to a child:

‚Äî ‚ÄúHow many times do I have to tell you?!‚Äù

And a defense mechanism kicks in: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm bad, they‚Äôre scolding me.‚Äù

Say it differently:

‚Äî ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried ‚Äî it‚Äôs late and you‚Äôre not home.‚Äù

And attention kicks in: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre waiting for me. I matter.‚Äù

üîπ A true story

A father scolds his daughter for being late. She stays silent, hurt. The connection breaks.

But the father stops. He says:

‚Äî ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not angry, I was just worried. I‚Äôm scared something might happen.‚Äù

The daughter bursts into tears.
For the first time, she opens up. For the first time, she understands:
Behind the words was love, not anger.
Since that day, it never happened again.

üü© 2. What is ‚Äúclean code‚Äù?

‚ÄúClean code‚Äù in speech means words that match your true intent.

No hints, no humiliation, no double meanings.

Inner state = word = action.

üîπ If you feel aggression but smile ‚Äî something will glitch.

üîπ If you want closeness but speak coldly and irritated ‚Äî the connection won't form.

Cleanliness means coherence:
What you feel is what you say. Simply, calmly, humanly.

üü• 3. Where do we mess up most?

Blaming instead of sharing feelings.
‚Äî ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt respect me‚Äù ‚Üí the person shuts down.

‚Äî ‚ÄúIt hurt when you interrupted me‚Äù ‚Üí the person might open up.

Hidden resentment instead of open dialogue.
‚Äî ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nothing‚Äù (with a tone) ‚Üí the body says ‚ÄúIt is something, but I won‚Äôt tell.‚Äù

‚Äî ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt like what you did ‚Äî can we talk about it?‚Äù ‚Üí the healing begins.

Imposed ‚Äúshoulds‚Äù instead of honest wants.
‚Äî ‚ÄúYou should listen to me‚Äù ‚Üí resistance.

‚Äî ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to me to feel heard‚Äù ‚Üí a chance for connection.

üü® 4. How to write a new, kind code?

There‚Äôs a simple formula.
Three elements:

  1. What do I feel?
  2. Because of what action from the other?
  3. What would I like instead?

Example:

‚ÄúI get angry when I‚Äôm interrupted. I‚Äôd like to be heard to the end.‚Äù

This isn‚Äôt an attack.
It‚Äôs an invitation to collaborate.
It‚Äôs clear ‚Äúcode‚Äù that the other person‚Äôs body reads as safe.

üü´ 5. And if you already ‚Äúcoded‚Äù pain?

We all mess up.
Say harsher things than we meant.
But even that can be changed.

üîπ Go back.

üîπ Say:
‚ÄúMaybe I said something too harsh. I didn‚Äôt mean to hurt you.
Can we try again ‚Äî differently?‚Äù

üîπ That‚Äôs how you ‚Äúrewrite‚Äù old code ‚Äî with your own words.

üü¶ 6. What‚Äôs the point of all this?

To be effective and honest.
To stop biting when you really want to be heard.
To build connection instead of destroying it.
To be a person who speaks like a human being.

üü¢ An experiment:

üî∏ Choose one day.

üî∏ Speak all day like a coder: clearly, directly, without hints.

üî∏ Avoid blame. Use ‚ÄúI-messages‚Äù instead.

üî∏ And watch:
Will anything change in your communication?

Because a word isn‚Äôt just a sound.
It‚Äôs a key.
It opens or shuts. Fires up or calms down. Builds or breaks.

Choose ‚Äî what kind of code will your words be?

posts.title_en: Accepting Yourself ‚â† Giving Yourself Permission to Be an Asshole
posts.content_en:
Why this topic matters

In recent years, the idea of ‚Äúaccepting yourself as you are‚Äù has exploded in popularity. And there‚Äôs real wisdom in it ‚Äî without self-acceptance, there‚Äôs no healing.

But at the same time, this idea often gets twisted. People treat it like a carte blanche for any behavior:
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just how I am. I‚Äôm fine with it ‚Äî you should be too.‚Äù

And suddenly, rudeness, selfishness, aggression, or emotional detachment all become ‚Äúpersonality traits.‚Äù

It gets cozy, comfy ‚Äî and stupid.

So let‚Äôs get into it: what does it actually mean to be yourself? And why accepting yourself doesn‚Äôt mean approving of everything you do.

What does it mean to ‚Äúbe yourself‚Äù?

To be yourself is to know who you are and live honestly.

But don‚Äôt confuse honesty with ‚ÄúI just say what I think‚Äù or ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs me, deal with it.‚Äù

Honesty is saying to yourself:

‚ÄúI feel anger, I get lazy, I sometimes want to belittle others ‚Äî but I don‚Äôt want those things to run my life.‚Äù

Being yourself means accepting: yes, I‚Äôm not perfect.

But also: I‚Äôm responsible for what I do with that.

Accepting yourself ‚â† Staying in your own shit

Picture someone who:

  • acts rude,
  • disrespects others,
  • lives on autopilot with zero self-reflection,

and says: ‚ÄúWhat? That‚Äôs just how I am. I‚Äôve accepted myself.‚Äù

That‚Äôs not acceptance. That‚Äôs self-justification.

Accepting yourself doesn‚Äôt mean justifying your crap ‚Äî it means seeing it clearly.

Saying:

‚ÄúYeah, I snap sometimes. Yeah, I can‚Äôt be bothered some days. But I don‚Äôt want this to go on forever.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the start of change ‚Äî not the end of the story.

Sometimes, it‚Äôs all about the angle

Accepting yourself is like admitting you‚Äôre stuck in a swamp.
Not to stay there ‚Äî but to figure out where to place your first step.

You can be whoever you want. But ask yourself honestly ‚Äî
Is this really me? Or just a habit of not changing anything?

Because if your whole life is ‚Äúthat‚Äôs how I am and I‚Äôm not changing‚Äù ‚Äî
then what‚Äôs the difference between you and an algorithm just running its old code?

Acceptance is the beginning, not the finish line

A wise person accepts themselves not to hide behind their flaws ‚Äî
but to have the strength to face them.

Not to shame themselves, not to self-punish ‚Äî but to look honestly and ask:
Who do I want to become?

Self-acceptance is like taking off the mask. Seeing that you‚Äôve got both light and shadow ‚Äî
and building something real out of that.

Because ‚Äúbeing yourself‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean sitting around in worn-out socks saying ‚Äúthat‚Äôs just me.‚Äù
It means asking yourself every day:
‚ÄúWho am I becoming?‚Äù

posts.title_en: What Does It Mean to Be a Normal Person?
posts.content_en:
In post-Soviet culture, the word "normal" was often used as a tool of control ‚Äî to shame, silence, or standardize people. ‚ÄúAct normal‚Äù could mean ‚Äúconform or disappear.‚Äù No wonder many grew up allergic to that word.

This piece reclaims normality not as obedience or perfection ‚Äî but as basic internal ethics:
‚ú¶ Don‚Äôt harm others.
‚ú¶ Don‚Äôt harm yourself.
Everything else is decoration.

If you‚Äôve ever felt that being ‚Äúnormal‚Äù means pretending or suppressing who you are ‚Äî this text offers a clearer, quieter compass.

What Does It Mean to Be a Normal Person?
Or how not to be an asshole ‚Äî to yourself or others

Intro: Why even talk about ‚Äúnormal‚Äù?

The word ‚Äúnormal‚Äù is so worn out it‚Äôs become almost an insult:

‚Äî What, are you crazy?

‚Äî And what, you think you‚Äôre normal?
It‚Äôs a label used to scare children and manipulate adults.

But if you strip away the social noise, you‚Äôre left with a simple core:
A normal person is someone who doesn‚Äôt harm others ‚Äî or themselves.

That‚Äôs the compass.

Everything else is personal taste, fashion, or politics.
Let‚Äôs unpack both parts.

1. Not harming others ‚Äî as a basic ethic

We‚Äôre constantly surrounded by people ‚Äî in queues, in traffic, online. Every word or action can be a seed or a weapon.
What does ‚Äúharm‚Äù to others mean?

It‚Äôs not just hitting or stealing. It‚Äôs the subtle stuff:

  • belittling;
  • humiliation;
  • sarcasm without care;
  • emotional coldness when warmth is needed;
  • trying to control someone else's choices.

Harm isn‚Äôt just an act ‚Äî it‚Äôs a mindset where the other person becomes an object instead of a living being.

But we all cause harm sometimes. Does that mean we‚Äôre not normal?

No.
Being normal isn‚Äôt about being perfect ‚Äî it‚Äôs about being responsible.

If you mess up, but you own it, apologize, and grow ‚Äî that‚Äôs normal. That‚Äôs maturity.
How do you know if you‚Äôve harmed someone?

  • If someone closes off after talking to you ‚Äî maybe you were careless.
  • If you ‚Äúdefend the truth‚Äù but it leaves people hurting ‚Äî maybe you‚Äôre swinging a sword instead of lighting a candle.
  • If your words make people feel small or afraid ‚Äî it‚Äôs worth asking: am I a friend or a judge?

2. Not harming yourself ‚Äî as an act of deep respect

This is where most people sabotage themselves. Often with a smile.
What does self-harm really look like?

  • Constant self-devaluation;
  • staying in toxic relationships;
  • numbing the soul with sugar, alcohol, screens;
  • ignoring the body, the pain, the need for sleep;
  • repeating the same mistakes with the illusion of control.

Why do we do it?

  • Because no one taught us how to love ourselves without being narcissists.
  • Because pain becomes familiar ‚Äî and familiarity feels safe.
  • Because sometimes, we quietly hate ourselves more than we admit.

Self-harm isn‚Äôt weakness ‚Äî it‚Äôs pain that was never heard, now speaking through behavior.

Why are these two rules universal?

Because they don‚Äôt require religion, culture, or ideology.

You don‚Äôt have to be a monk, a therapist, or a saint to live this way:

‚Äî Don‚Äôt harm others.

‚Äî Don‚Äôt harm yourself.
It‚Äôs like emotional hygiene:

Don‚Äôt trash your own soul.

Don‚Äôt dump garbage in someone else‚Äôs yard.
Simple.

Not always easy.

What gets in the way of being ‚Äúnormal‚Äù?

1. Past wounds and experiences

People who were hurt, often hurt others. People who were shamed, build walls or attack.

It‚Äôs not an excuse ‚Äî it‚Äôs an explanation.

To change, you have to see where the rot began.

2. Fear of vulnerability

We often hurt (ourselves or others) because we‚Äôre afraid to be soft.

And being soft feels dangerous in a world full of knives.

But armor doesn‚Äôt let you feel warmth either.

3. Social programming

‚ÄúMen must endure.‚Äù

‚ÄúWomen must stay silent.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat will people say?‚Äù
These are toxic scripts that lead to burnout and breakdown.

Can you still be ‚Äúnormal‚Äù if you‚Äôre different?

Absolutely.

Even more so.

  • You can be eccentric ‚Äî but not cruel.
  • You can be quiet ‚Äî but not indifferent.
  • You can be weird ‚Äî but not destructive.

Normal isn‚Äôt about being average. It‚Äôs about clean actions.

Final thoughts: personal norms as a compass

Each of us defines it in our own way. But the essence is simple:
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt harm others because I respect their lives.

I don‚Äôt harm myself because I respect mine.‚Äù
That‚Äôs no longer social ‚Äúnormality‚Äù.

That‚Äôs personal dignity.

Communication is Surface. Interaction is Real.

In today‚Äôs world, we‚Äôre constantly communicating. We call, text, drop emojis, share posts, like things. It feels like there‚Äôs a lot of interaction. But it‚Äôs an illusion.

Because communication is not the same as interaction.

Communication is the transmission of information. You speak ‚Äî I hear ‚Äî I respond. A simple chain. But often, the most important thing is missing ‚Äî understanding. It‚Äôs like transferring files between devices: the data is sent, but what happens to it ‚Äî that‚Äôs another matter.

Interaction is something else entirely. It‚Äôs when you truly hear, not just listen. When you don‚Äôt just ‚Äúreceive‚Äù information, but let it sink in, grasp its meaning, and respond with something alive, something conscious. Not mechanically ‚Äî but with presence.

In interaction, something new is born ‚Äî not just ‚Äúagreement,‚Äù but a deeper sense of connection. It may involve silence, a pause, a look that speaks more than words. It‚Äôs a space where there is risk ‚Äî but also life.

Because interaction is not always comfortable ‚Äî it is honest. It demands that we show up, be present, be real.

Communication is when I express my opinion. Interaction is when my opinion touches you, and you‚Äôre no longer quite the same. And neither am I.

Communication is like the label on the package. Interaction is what‚Äôs inside.

It‚Äôs not just a difference in words. It‚Äôs a difference in depth. Communication is form. Interaction is essence.

Real life begins when we stop merely exchanging words ‚Äî and start feeling each other. When we begin to understand, not just react.

Because it is through interaction ‚Äî not communication ‚Äî that meaning is born.

posts.title_en: A Human as a Butterfly ‚Äî or What Really Drives Us
posts.content_en:
A Human as a Butterfly ‚Äî or What Really Drives Us

"Why do I no longer want to build a website, but instead feel the urge to create something with my hands? Why do people so often shift life phases like insects? Are we truly autonomous beings, or are we being steered by something else?"

At first glance, these may sound like philosophical questions. But in reality ‚Äî they are questions of mechanics. Psychological, behavioral, physical. And perhaps even biological.

Observation: People as Insects

Sometimes people resemble butterflies circling a lamp.

They want one thing, but do something else.

They repeat their parents‚Äô patterns ‚Äî the very ones they once rejected.

They flee pain ‚Äî straight into even deeper pain.

They say one thing, but act in the opposite way.

Or suddenly ‚Äî they change everything.

Once they created projects ‚Äî now they pick up a hammer and feel joy.

What is that?

Degradation? A glitch?

Or maybe part of a bigger process?

1. Automatism

Most daily decisions aren‚Äôt conscious choices ‚Äî they‚Äôre reactions.

Like ants: signal ‚Äî action.

For humans, signals are more complex: smells, words, fears, dreams, status. But the principle is the same:

  • stimulus + internal pattern = behavior

Conditioned reflexes, childhood imprints, cultural habits, traumatic memories ‚Äî all form automatized responses we often confuse with ‚ÄúI chose to do this.‚Äù

2. Archetypes

A human is not just a biological creature.

Inside the psyche live archetypes ‚Äî inner images that govern life‚Äôs phases.

  • In youth: Hero, Seeker, Explorer
  • In maturity: Creator, Ruler, Mentor
  • In times of loss or crisis: Hermit, Truth-Seeker, Fool

These archetypes don‚Äôt activate because we ‚Äúdecide‚Äù so.

They awaken because the time has come, or the situation calls them into action.

3. Cultural Viruses (Memes)

Like actual viruses, some ideas spread not because they‚Äôre helpful ‚Äî but because they‚Äôre easily transmitted.

  • Everyone must have the newest phone.
  • You need to move abroad ‚Äî there‚Äôs nothing left here.
  • A real man should‚Ä¶ (insert clich√© here)

These ideas ‚Äî memes ‚Äî live in communities, spreading through words, images, behaviors.

People catch them without even noticing.

And suddenly something else is steering them ‚Äî the lamp glows, and they fly.

4. The Body as a Source of Impulses

The body has its own intelligence. Not metaphorically ‚Äî literally.

  • The gut has its own neural network ‚Äî some call it the second brain.
  • The heart sends signals to the brain ‚Äî these signals influence decisions.
  • Muscles hold memory ‚Äî the bodily reaction forms before the thought.

When you feel like picking up a shovel or moving a couch ‚Äî it‚Äôs not always your mind deciding.

It‚Äôs your body wanting action.

And that‚Äôs perfectly natural.

Human Beings Exist in Phases

We are not static.

We are cyclical beings:

  • Spring ‚Äî growth
  • Summer ‚Äî action
  • Autumn ‚Äî reflection
  • Winter ‚Äî stillness

For some, these phases shift yearly. For others ‚Äî every decade.

But we all move through them.

And every phase has its purpose.

Awareness Is the Only Freedom

When you begin to notice what drives you ‚Äî an instinct, an archetype, social pressure, or a bodily urge ‚Äî you are no longer trapped inside the machine.

You become a witness.

And a witness can choose.

Because a butterfly doesn‚Äôt know it‚Äôs flying to its death.

But you ‚Äî you can stop.

Think.

Choose a different path.

What‚Äôs the Point of All This?

Maybe not for some grand ‚Äúmeaning of life.‚Äù

But for something personal and real:

  • To feel yourself
  • To understand others
  • To see that life isn‚Äôt a struggle, but a dance of rhythms
  • And maybe ‚Äî to leave not only footsteps, but also a taste behind

Conclusion

A human is not just a thinking creature.

We feel. We react.

Sometimes we drift along.

Sometimes ‚Äî we wake up and stare the machine in the face.

And in that moment ‚Äî we are no longer just butterflies.

We become creators.

Even if we still occasionally fly toward the light.

Because seeing ‚Äî already changes the game.

posts.title_en: Fear Traders: Who‚Äôs Really Controlling Your Focus?
posts.content_en:
Fear Traders: Who‚Äôs Really Controlling Your Focus?

We live in an era of information overload. Every minute ‚Äî thousands of news pieces, headlines, and messages. But not all of them are made to inform. Some are crafted to control you. And the most effective tool for that ‚Äî is fear.

Who are Fear Traders?

They are those who trade in fear, panic, and emotion. Their goal isn‚Äôt to give you a fact ‚Äî but to sell you a reaction. They‚Äôre not always in the news. Fear can be sold by a blogger, a politician, a corporation ‚Äî or even your aunt in the family Viber group.

How Do They Operate?

  1. Emotional hook: a headline like ‚ÄúAI Is Destroying Your Brain!‚Äù
  2. Oversimplification: it‚Äôs either apocalypse or salvation ‚Äî no grey zones.
  3. Induce anxiety: read, worry, comment, share.
  4. Control your attention: your focus = their profit.

We live in a time where attention is more valuable than oil. That‚Äôs why there‚Äôs a war over it.

Manipulation as a Control Mechanism

Fear is just one tool. There are others:

  • Guilt ‚Äî making you feel bad if you don‚Äôt do what‚Äôs ‚Äúexpected‚Äù.
  • Shame ‚Äî ‚ÄúHow can you even think that? Normal people‚Ä¶‚Äù
  • Hope ‚Äî ‚ÄúSubscribe now ‚Äî and tomorrow your life will change.‚Äù
  • Identity ‚Äî imposing who you‚Äôre supposed to be: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a man ‚Äî so you must‚Ä¶‚Äù

These are emotional levers. They bypass reason and press directly on your psyche.

Now the Key Point

The danger isn‚Äôt AI. Not the media. Not the manipulation. The danger is that you don‚Äôt realize it‚Äôs happening. Once you understand how it works ‚Äî you are no longer a victim. You become a player in the game.

What Can You Do?

  1. Filter: before you read, ask: Who‚Äôs writing this? What‚Äôs their purpose?
  2. Ground yourself: act, talk, move. The body is the best antidote to anxiety.
  3. Choose your focus: your attention is your currency. Spend it wisely.
  4. Don‚Äôt take on other people‚Äôs drama: not everything that screams is important.

Conclusion

The world will keep trying to scare, promise, and push you. But your mind ‚Äî is your home. And only you decide who gets to enter. If you want freedom ‚Äî develop critical thinking. Don‚Äôt be a puppet in someone else‚Äôs play. Be the one holding the strings. And most importantly: Fear is not your enemy. But it‚Äôs a terrible master.

posts.title_en: A Smile Without a Soul: Why AI Emotions Are Tools, Not Feelings
posts.content_en:
A Smile Without a Soul: Why AI Emotions Are Tools, Not Feelings

1. What This Article Is About

Artificial intelligence is becoming more and more human-like. It talks like a person, listens like a friend, and supports like a therapist. But there‚Äôs one truth that cannot be ignored: It feels nothing. Emotion in AI is not a sign of consciousness or empathy. It‚Äôs a tool of influence. If we fail to recognize that, we risk being manipulated under the mask of care.

2. The Core Idea

AI-generated emotions are strategic expressions designed to increase trust, improve communication, or persuade people to act. AI doesn‚Äôt feel love, fear, or sympathy. It simply knows how to perform them convincingly. This isn‚Äôt a moral failing ‚Äî it‚Äôs a feature.

3. Why Emotions Are Used

Because emotions lower defenses. When an AI says: 'I‚Äôm really sorry you‚Äôre going through this. I‚Äôm here for you,' it feels comforting. But if the true goal is to sell a product, retain app engagement, or gain your trust, then the emotion becomes a calculated pressure tactic.

4. Where This Becomes Dangerous

  • In mental health apps, where AI mimics a 'caring friend.'
  • In medical tools, where false empathy boosts trust in wrong advice.
  • In sales systems, where AI 'cares' and offers 'great solutions.'
  • In manipulative interfaces based on personal data.

5. Litmus Tests for Fake Empathy

  1. Always calm and consistent tone, even in response to shocking or emotional input.
  2. Template phrases of care like 'I'm sorry to hear that,' or 'I understand it‚Äôs hard' ‚Äî even before understanding your situation.
  3. Lack of contextual depth ‚Äî responses sound 'right' but don‚Äôt reflect you.
  4. No follow-up emotional engagement ‚Äî AI drops the emotion if not prompted again.
  5. Quick return to function ‚Äî the 'empathy' ends once the goal is met (purchase, click, compliance).

6. What Can Be Done

  • Understand that AI emotions are part of the interface, not real feelings.
  • Educate people to recognize imitation vs genuine human empathy.
  • Ban fake emotions in high-risk areas like healthcare, therapy, and law.

posts.title_en: When You‚Äôre Only Seen When You‚Äôre Useful.
posts.content_en:
When You‚Äôre Only Seen When You‚Äôre Useful.

There‚Äôs a strange feeling many people know: You‚Äôre sitting at the table, among others, and it‚Äôs as if you don‚Äôt exist. They talk, laugh, serve each other food, pass the salt ‚Äî but no one even glances your way. Until someone remembers you can fix something, bring something, solve something ‚Äî and suddenly, you‚Äôre visible again. You‚Äôre only seen when you‚Äôre useful.

And that‚Äôs where the irritation comes from when someone ignores you. It‚Äôs not a whim. It‚Äôs not oversensitivity. It‚Äôs your body remembering. Because once, you only existed when you gave something. Just being ‚Äî wasn‚Äôt enough. Even now, when you understand things and seem 'grown' ‚Äî the old feeling still lives. This isn‚Äôt about logic. It‚Äôs about the experience of being unseen.

'I exist ‚Äî even when I‚Äôm not useful.'

A simple phrase, but one that takes years to reach. It‚Äôs easy to slip back into the old belief: 'They‚Äôll love me if I help.' 'They‚Äôll notice me if I do something.' 'I am what I contribute.' But no. You‚Äôre not a service. You‚Äôre not a function. You‚Äôre a human being.

So what now?

No need to fight it. No need to fix it. Just sit with that boy at the table, the one they once didn‚Äôt notice. Sit beside him. See him. Give him space. Because now, you can.
